title: Popular energy drinks linked to cardiac arrests
text:
'They're not lolly water': Popular energy drinks linked to cardiac arrests Posted Thu 16 Feb 2017, 2:27pm Updated Thu 16 Feb 2017, 3:17pm Popular energy drinks linked to cardiac arrests 
New research shows young people with no known history of heart disease are at risk of a fatal cardiac arrest after just one energy drink. 
The Royal Prince Alfred Hospital study found patients with a disorder called Long QT Syndrome had a significant increase in their blood pressure after drinking a single can of Red Bull. 
Long QT Syndrome is a genetic heart disorder that affects about one in 2000 Australians. Although it's relatively common, many people are not aware they have it. 
"The study found energy drinks can cause two main things - alter the blood pressure and also alter the rhythm of the heart," said cardiologist Dr Chris Semsarian, one of the authors of the study. 
That can cause very serious problems and even death." Skip YouTube Video FireFox NVDA users - To access the following content, press 'M' to enter the iFrame. 
In the study, people with Long QT Syndrome were given Red Bull. One in eight experienced a faster heart rate and the rhythm became more erratic. 
"It changes the normal rhythm of the heart to a rhythm that can lead to bad problems - it didn't actually cause the problems themselves." 
He pointed out that in the study patients were given only one can each of Red Bull, but often people drink up to five in one night. He said it was not known what specific ingredient, or combination of ingredients, was causing the heart problems. 
"The caffeine contributes, but it's a combination of caffeine being drunk quickly, as well as taurine and guarana and further stimulants. 
"We also don't know what some of those drinks have in them." Calls for ban on sales to under-18s 
Energy drinks have been under the spotlight for the last few years. 
In the United States, a class action lawsuit is being brought against the energy drink company Monster on behalf of people who have suffered "serious, permanent and life-altering injuries as a result of regular consumption," according to the prosecuting law firm. 
It follows other lawsuits against Mother. In 2013, the parent of a Californian teenager who died from cardiac arrhythmia sued the company, alleging the death was the result of her son drinking two cans of Monster Energy daily for three years. In 2015, the wife of a man who died after drinking one can of Monster Energy every day for two weeks sued Monster. Both cases settled out of court. Drink/product
